news_summary: Today's space news celebrates decades of scientific advancements on the International Space Station, innovative student-led efforts in space agriculture, new insights from the BioSentinel mission, and potential discovery of the largest stars ever observed.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui célèbre des décennies d'avancées scientifiques sur la Station spatiale internationale, des efforts novateurs menés par des étudiants dans le domaine de l'agriculture spatiale, de nouvelles connaissances issues de la mission BioSentinel et la découverte potentielle des plus grandes étoiles jamais observées.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy celebran décadas de avances científicos en la Estación Espacial Internacional, los innovadores esfuerzos de los estudiantes en la agricultura espacial, los nuevos conocimientos de la misión BioSentinel y el posible descubrimiento de las estrellas más grandes jamás observadas.

articles.title: 25 Years of Scientific Discovery Aboard the International Space Station
articles.summary: November marks 25 years of human presence aboard the International Space Station, a testament to international collaboration and human ingenuity. Since the first crew arrived on Nov. 2, 2000, NASA and its partners have conducted thousands of research investigations and technology demonstrations to advance exploration of the Moon and Mars and benefit life on Earth. […]
articles.content:
November marks 25 years of human presence aboard the International Space Station, a testament to international collaboration and human ingenuity. Since the first crew arrived on Nov. 2, 2000, NASA and its partners have conducted thousands of research investigations and technology demonstrations to advance exploration of the Moon and Mars and benefit life on Earth.

Researchers have taken advantage of the unique microgravity environment to conduct experiments impossible to replicate on Earth, transforming research across disciplines. More than 4,000 experiments have pushed the boundaries of science, sparked discoveries, and driven scientific breakthroughs.

“25 years ago, Expedition 1 became the first crew to call the International Space Station home, beginning a period of continuous human presence in space that still continues to this day,” said NASA acting administrator Sean Duffy. “This historic milestone would not have been possible without NASA and its partners, as well as every astronaut and engineer who works to keep the lights on in low Earth orbit.”

To celebrate a quarter century of innovation in microgravity, NASA is highlighting 25 scientific breakthroughs that exemplify the station’s enduring impact on science, technology, and exploration.

Building the road to the Moon and Mars

The waxing crescent moon appears just above the Earth’s atmosphere as the International Space Station orbits the Earth. NASA

NASA uses the space station as a proving ground to develop new systems and technologies for missions beyond low Earth orbit.

Navigation, communication, and radiation shielding technologies proven aboard the space station are being integrated into spacecraft and missions to reach the Moon and Mars.

Robotic systems, for example a robotic surgeon and autonomous assistants, will expand available medical procedures and allow astronauts to dedicate time to more crucial tasks during missions far from Earth.

Astronauts have used recycled plastic and stainless steel to 3D print tools and parts. The ability to 3D print in space lays the groundwork for on-demand repair and fabrication during future deep space missions where resupply isn’t readily available.

From the deployment of the first wooden satellite to laser communications and self-healing quantum communications, the space station is a proving ground for cutting-edge space technologies.

Why this matters:

Humanity’s push to the Moon and Mars begins with discoveries in low Earth orbit. From demonstrating how astronauts can live, work, and repair equipment off Earth to testing life-support systems and advanced materials, every innovation aboard the station helps to advance NASA’s Artemis and other exploration initiatives and brings humanity closer to thriving beyond our planet.

Sustaining life beyond Earth

NASA astronauts Jessica Watkins, front, and Bob Hines, back, work on XROOTS aboard the International Space Station. This experiment used the station’s Veggie facility to test soilless hydroponic and aeroponic plant growth. NASA

As NASA prepares to return humans to the Moon through the Artemis program and push onward to Mars, sustaining life beyond Earth is more critical than ever.

Astronauts have grown more than 50 species of plants in space, including tomatoes, bok choi, romaine lettuce, and chili peppers.

Advanced life support systems are capable of recycling up to 98% of water in the U.S. segment aboard the space station, the ideal level needed for exploration missions.

Crew health data shows how space affects the brain, vision, balance and control, and muscle and bone density, guiding strategies to maintain astronaut performance during extended missions and improve health on Earth.

Researchers have sequenced DNA in orbit and are advancing techniques to enable real-time assessment of microbial life in space, which is essential to maintaining astronaut health.

Why this matters:

By growing food, recycling water, and improving medical care in space, NASA is paving the way for future long-duration missions to the Moon and Mars while revolutionizing agriculture and medicine back home.

Helping humanity on Earth

Pharmaceutical crystals grown aboard the International Space Station are shown after returning to Earth. Redwire

Research aboard the orbiting laboratory not only pushes humanity farther into the cosmos but can help address complex human health issues on the ground. By providing a platform for long-term microgravity research, the space station fosters breakthroughs that yield direct benefits to people on Earth.

Research aboard the space station provides new insights to develop treatments for diseases like cancer, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and heart disease by revealing how microgravity alters cellular functions.

New developments in medicine for cancer, muscular dystrophy, and neurodegenerative diseases have come from growing protein crystals in microgravity with larger, more organized structures.

High quality stem cells can be grown in greater quantities in space, helping to develop new regenerative therapies for neurological, cardiovascular, and immunological conditions.

Pioneering efforts in 3D bioprinting, which uses cells, proteins, and nutrients as source material, have produced human tissue structures such as a knee meniscus and heart tissue, a major step toward manufacturing organs in space for transplant patients on Earth.

Researchers are using miniaturized tissue models to observe how space affects tissues and organ systems, offering new ways to develop and test medicines to protect astronauts on future missions and improve treatments on Earth.

Photos taken by astronauts have supported emergency response to natural disasters, such as hurricanes, with targeted views from space.

Instruments mounted on the space station protect critical space infrastructure and provide data on the planet’s natural patterns by measuring Earth’s resources and space weather.

Why this matters:

Microgravity research is moving us closer to manufacturing human organs in space for transplant and revealing new ways to fight cancer, heart disease, osteoporosis, neurodegenerative disease, and other serious illnesses that affect millions of people worldwide. The station also serves as an observation platform to monitor natural disasters, weather patterns, and Earth’s resources.

Understanding our universe

Artist concept of operations inside NASA’s Cold Atom Laboratory aboard the International Space Station. NASA

The space station offers scientists an unparalleled vantage point to learn about the fundamental behavior of the universe. By studying cosmic phenomena typically blocked or absorbed by Earth’s atmosphere and observing physics at an atomic level, researchers can probe mysteries impossible to study from Earth.

Why this matters:

Research aboard the space station is helping us unravel the deepest mysteries of our universe, from the smallest quantum particles to the most powerful cosmic explosions. Observations of collapsing stars and black holes could inspire new navigation tools using cosmic signals and expand our grasp of space-time. Studies of antimatter and dark matter bring us closer to understanding the 95% of the universe invisible to the human eye. Creating the fifth state of matter in space unlocks new quantum pathways that could transform technology on Earth and in space.

Learning new physics

This image shows a flame ignited as part of the Flame Design investigation on the International Space Station. NASA

Physical processes behave differently in microgravity, offering scientists a new lens for discovery.

Engineers can design more efficient fuel and life support systems for future spacecraft thanks to studies of fluid boiling, containment, and flow.

Analyzing gels and liquids mixed with tiny particles in space helps researchers fine-tune material compositions and has led to new patents for consumer products.

The discovery of cool flames in space, a phenomenon difficult to study on Earth, has opened new frontiers in combustion science and engine design.

Why this matters:

Breakthroughs in fundamental physics aboard the space station drive innovation on Earth and advance spacecraft fuel, thermal control, plant watering, and water purification systems. Research in soft materials is improving products in medicine, household products, and renewable energy, while cool flames studies may lead to cleaner, more efficient engines.

Enabling global access to space

NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers talks on a ham radio with students from Lakeside Junior High School in Springdale, Arkansas. Ayers answered questions from the students about her experience living and working aboard the International Space Station. NASA

Since 2000, the space station has opened doors for private companies, researchers, students, and astronauts around the world to participate in exploration and help propel humanity forward to the Moon and Mars.

The space station is a launchpad for the commercial space economy, enabling private astronaut missions and hosting hundreds of experiments from commercial companies, giving them the chance to strengthen their technologies through in-orbit research, manufacturing demonstrations, and innovation.

CubeSats deployed from the space station enable students and innovators around the world to test radio antennas, small telescopes, and other scientific demonstrations in space.

More than one million students have engaged with astronauts via ham radio events, inspiring the next generation to participate in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

More than 285 crew members from more than 25 countries have visited humanity’s longest-operating outpost in space, making it a symbol of global collaboration.

Why this matters:

The space station has enabled the space economy, where commercial research, manufacturing, and technology demonstrations are shaping a new global marketplace. NASA and its international partners have established a leadership position in low Earth orbit, creating new opportunities for industry and paving the way for exploration missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond.

Learn more about the research aboard the International Space Station at:

www.nasa.gov/iss-science

Revisit the 20th anniversary for more information.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights 25 years of continuous human presence aboard the International Space Station, showcasing significant scientific breakthroughs, technological innovations, and international collaboration that benefit humanity broadly. It details advances in space exploration, health, technology, and Earth observation with substantial real-world impact and inspiring scope.
articles.personality_title: Celebrating 25 years of discovery on the International Space Station
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since November 2, 2000, astronauts have lived and worked continuously on the International Space Station (ISS), a space laboratory orbiting Earth. This station is a joint project involving NASA and international partners, designed to support scientific research and prepare for future space missions.

**What happened** – This November marks the 25th anniversary of humans living aboard the ISS. Over these years, crews have conducted more than 4,000 experiments in microgravity, exploring areas like biology, physics, medicine, and technology. The station has helped develop new tools, tested life support systems, and grown plants in space. It has also supported research that benefits health and technology on Earth.

**Impact** – The ISS has been essential for learning how to live and work in space, which helps NASA plan missions to the Moon and Mars. Experiments on the station have improved water recycling, medical treatments, and even 3D printing in space. Research done there has advanced cancer and disease studies, improved materials, and helped monitor Earth’s environment and natural disasters.

**What's next step** – NASA and its partners will continue using the ISS to test new technologies and conduct experiments. These efforts will support upcoming missions under programs like Artemis, which aims to send humans back to the Moon and eventually to Mars. The station also remains a platform for international cooperation and for private companies to develop space technologies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The International Space Station’s 25 years of continuous human presence have driven important scientific discoveries and technology advances that prepare humanity for future space exploration and improve life on Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: 25 ans de découvertes scientifiques à bord de la Station spatiale internationale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis le 2 novembre 2000, des astronautes vivent et travaillent en continu à bord de la Station spatiale internationale (ISS), un laboratoire spatial en orbite autour de la Terre. Cette station est un projet commun de la NASA et de partenaires internationaux, destinée à soutenir la recherche scientifique et à préparer les futures missions spatiales.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En novembre, la présence humaine continue à bord de l’ISS fête ses 25 ans. Pendant cette période, les équipages ont réalisé plus de 4 000 expériences en microgravité, explorant la biologie, la physique, la médecine et la technologie. La station a aidé à développer de nouveaux outils, testé des systèmes de survie et cultivé des plantes dans l’espace. Elle a aussi soutenu des recherches bénéfiques pour la santé et la technologie sur Terre.

**Impact** – L’ISS a été essentielle pour apprendre à vivre et travailler dans l’espace, ce qui aide la NASA à préparer des missions vers la Lune et Mars. Les expériences ont amélioré le recyclage de l’eau, les traitements médicaux et même l’impression 3D dans l’espace. Les recherches ont fait progresser les études sur le cancer et d’autres maladies, amélioré les matériaux et aidé à surveiller l’environnement terrestre et les catastrophes naturelles.

**Prochaine étape** – La NASA et ses partenaires continueront d’utiliser l’ISS pour tester de nouvelles technologies et mener des expériences. Ces efforts soutiendront les futures missions comme le programme Artemis, qui vise à renvoyer des humains sur la Lune puis sur Mars. La station reste aussi une plateforme de coopération internationale et de développement de technologies spatiales par des entreprises privées.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les 25 ans de présence humaine continue à bord de la Station spatiale internationale ont permis des découvertes scientifiques et des avancées technologiques importantes, préparant l’exploration spatiale future et améliorant la vie sur Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: 25 años de descubrimientos científicos a bordo de la Estación Espacial Internacional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde el 2 de noviembre de 2000, los astronautas viven y trabajan de forma continua en la Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI), un laboratorio espacial que orbita la Tierra. Esta estación es un proyecto conjunto de la NASA y socios internacionales, diseñada para apoyar la investigación científica y preparar futuras misiones espaciales.

**Qué pasó** – Este noviembre se cumplen 25 años de presencia humana continua en la EEI. Durante este tiempo, las tripulaciones han realizado más de 4,000 experimentos en microgravedad, explorando áreas como biología, física, medicina y tecnología. La estación ha ayudado a desarrollar nuevas herramientas, probar sistemas de soporte vital y cultivar plantas en el espacio. También ha apoyado investigaciones que benefician la salud y la tecnología en la Tierra.

**Impacto** – La EEI ha sido clave para aprender a vivir y trabajar en el espacio, lo que ayuda a la NASA a planificar misiones a la Luna y Marte. Los experimentos han mejorado el reciclaje de agua, tratamientos médicos e incluso la impresión 3D en el espacio. Las investigaciones han avanzado en estudios sobre el cáncer y otras enfermedades, mejorado materiales y ayudado a monitorear el medio ambiente y desastres naturales.

**Próximo paso** – La NASA y sus socios continuarán usando la EEI para probar nuevas tecnologías y realizar experimentos. Estos esfuerzos apoyarán misiones futuras bajo programas como Artemis, que busca llevar humanos de nuevo a la Luna y luego a Marte. La estación sigue siendo una plataforma para la cooperación internacional y para que empresas privadas desarrollen tecnologías espaciales.

**Una frase clave** – Los 25 años de presencia humana continua en la Estación Espacial Internacional han impulsado importantes descubrimientos científicos y avances tecnológicos que preparan la exploración espacial futura y mejoran la vida en la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, intricately connected space station orbiting Earth beneath a crescent Moon, surrounded by symbolic representations of scientific discovery—floating 3D-printed tools, sprouting hydroponic plants, and delicate crystalline structures—set against a soft, natural color palette of blues, greens, and gentle earth tones.

articles.title: 10 Years of Students Helping NASA Grow Space Food with Growing Beyond Earth
articles.summary: Nearly 1,250 middle and high school students from 71 schools around the world joined Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden for the Growing Beyond Earth (GBE) Student Launch Chat with the Scientists, marking an inspiring milestone in the program’s 10th anniversary year. The live session, held in collaboration with NASA, connected classrooms directly with Dr. Gioia Massa […]
articles.content:
Students from 71 Classrooms engaged with NASA scientists to learn about how their Growing Beyond Earth research is contributing to feeding astronauts for long distance space travel.

Nearly 1,250 middle and high school students from 71 schools around the world joined Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden for the Growing Beyond Earth (GBE) Student Launch Chat with the Scientists, marking an inspiring milestone in the program’s 10th anniversary year.

The live session, held in collaboration with NASA, connected classrooms directly with Dr. Gioia Massa and Trent M. Smith, senior leaders of NASA Kennedy Space Center’s Space Crop Production team. Students heard firsthand how their classroom experiments are helping NASA identify and grow the best crops for future astronauts on long-duration missions to the Moon and Mars.

“Our students are contributing to real NASA science,” said one participating teacher. “It’s incredibly motivating for them to know their data could influence what astronauts eat in space someday.”

Connecting Classrooms with NASA Science

Growing Beyond Earth, led by Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden in Miami, Florida, brings authentic NASA research into classrooms in a way that few science programs can. For more than a decade, the 83-acre botanic garden – renowned for its conservation, education, and research programs – has worked hand-in-hand with NASA to advance understanding of food production in space.

Students use specially designed plant growth chambers to test how different crops perform under conditions that mimic spacecraft environments. The data they collect are shared with NASA scientists, who use the findings to refine ongoing space crop production research.

Since the program’s inception, more than 120,000 students across 800+ classrooms have tested over 250 plant cultivars, with five student-tested crops already grown aboard the International Space Station.

Cultivating the Future STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, & Mathematics) Workforce

The Growing Beyond Earth project exemplifies the mission of NASA’s Science Activation (SciAct) program, which connects NASA Science with people of all ages and backgrounds in ways that activate minds and promote a deeper understanding of our world and beyond, with the ultimate Vision: To increase learners’ active participation in the advancement of human knowledge. By engaging students as active participants in cutting-edge research, projects like GBE not only advance NASA’s goals but also cultivate curiosity, creativity, and confidence in the next generation of scientists and explorers. This year’s GBE Student Launch Chat celebrated that impact, showing how student research from classrooms around the globe contributes to the future of space exploration.

“When students see themselves as part of NASA’s mission, they realize science isn’t something distant, it’s something they can do,” said Dr. Massa. Teacher Espy Rodriguez from Hialeah Senior High School said, "It made their [her students] projects matter. I think it gave the kids a real sense of community. We are far, but we are one." By growing plants, analyzing data, and sharing results with NASA, these students are helping humanity prepare for life beyond Earth, proving that the seeds of tomorrow’s discoveries are being planted in today’s classrooms.

GBE is supported by NASA under cooperative agreement award number 80NCCS2M0125 and is part of NASA’s Science Activation Portfolio. Learn more about how Science Activation connects NASA science experts, real content, and experiences with community leaders to do science in ways that activate minds and promote deeper understanding of our world and beyond: https://science.nasa.gov/learn/about-science-activation/.

www.fairchildgarden.org/gbe
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a decade-long educational program where thousands of students worldwide actively contribute to NASA's space crop research, directly impacting future long-duration space missions. It demonstrates broad positive real-world impact by engaging and inspiring the next generation in STEM and space exploration, with substantial substance and clear benefits beyond a niche audience.
articles.personality_title: Students worldwide help NASA grow food for space missions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For the past 10 years, NASA and Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden have worked together on a program called Growing Beyond Earth (GBE). This program invites middle and high school students to grow plants and study how they might be used to feed astronauts on long space trips.

**What happened** – Nearly 1,250 students from 71 schools around the world joined a live chat with NASA scientists Dr. Gioia Massa and Trent M. Smith. During this event, students learned how their experiments with plant growth chambers help NASA figure out which crops grow best in space-like conditions. These experiments are important because some of the crops tested by students are already being grown on the International Space Station.

**Impact** – This program is special because it lets students do real science that helps prepare for future missions to the Moon and Mars. It also encourages young people to get interested in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Teachers say that knowing their work might influence what astronauts eat makes students feel motivated and connected to NASA’s mission.

**What’s next step** – The Growing Beyond Earth program will continue to involve students worldwide in space crop research. NASA will use the data collected by students to improve how plants are grown in space, supporting longer and more challenging missions. This ongoing work helps train the next generation of scientists and explorers.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Through Growing Beyond Earth, thousands of students worldwide are helping NASA grow food for astronauts, turning classrooms into places where space exploration begins.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des élèves du monde entier aident la NASA à cultiver la nourriture pour l’espace
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis 10 ans, la NASA et le Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden collaborent sur un programme appelé Growing Beyond Earth (GBE). Ce programme invite des élèves de collège et lycée à cultiver des plantes et étudier comment elles pourraient nourrir les astronautes lors de longs voyages spatiaux.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Près de 1 250 élèves de 71 écoles dans le monde ont participé à une discussion en direct avec les scientifiques de la NASA, le Dr Gioia Massa et Trent M. Smith. Pendant cet événement, les élèves ont découvert comment leurs expériences avec des chambres de croissance de plantes aident la NASA à choisir les meilleures cultures pour les conditions spatiales. Certaines plantes testées par les élèves sont déjà cultivées sur la Station spatiale internationale.

**Impact** – Ce programme est spécial car il permet aux élèves de faire de la vraie science qui prépare les futures missions vers la Lune et Mars. Il encourage aussi les jeunes à s’intéresser aux sciences, technologies, ingénierie et mathématiques (STIM). Les enseignants disent que savoir que leur travail pourrait influencer l’alimentation des astronautes motive et rapproche les élèves de la mission de la NASA.

**Prochaine étape** – Le programme Growing Beyond Earth continuera à impliquer des élèves du monde entier dans la recherche sur les cultures spatiales. La NASA utilisera les données collectées pour améliorer la culture des plantes dans l’espace, soutenant des missions plus longues et plus difficiles. Ce travail forme aussi la prochaine génération de scientifiques et explorateurs.

**En une phrase** – Grâce à Growing Beyond Earth, des milliers d’élèves participent à aider la NASA à cultiver la nourriture des astronautes, transformant les salles de classe en lieux où commence l’exploration spatiale.
articles.personality_title_es: Estudiantes de todo el mundo ayudan a la NASA a cultivar alimentos para misiones espaciales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante los últimos 10 años, la NASA y el Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden han trabajado juntos en un programa llamado Growing Beyond Earth (GBE). Este programa invita a estudiantes de secundaria a cultivar plantas y estudiar cómo podrían alimentar a los astronautas en viajes espaciales largos.

**Qué pasó** – Casi 1,250 estudiantes de 71 escuelas alrededor del mundo participaron en una charla en vivo con los científicos de la NASA, la Dra. Gioia Massa y Trent M. Smith. Durante el evento, los estudiantes aprendieron cómo sus experimentos con cámaras de crecimiento de plantas ayudan a la NASA a identificar los mejores cultivos para condiciones similares al espacio. Algunas plantas probadas por los estudiantes ya se cultivan en la Estación Espacial Internacional.

**Impacto** – Este programa es especial porque permite que los estudiantes hagan ciencia real que ayuda a preparar futuras misiones a la Luna y Marte. También motiva a los jóvenes a interesarse en ciencia, tecnología, ingeniería y matemáticas (STEM). Los maestros dicen que saber que su trabajo podría influir en la comida de los astronautas hace que los estudiantes se sientan motivados y conectados con la misión de la NASA.

**Próximo paso** – El programa Growing Beyond Earth seguirá involucrando a estudiantes de todo el mundo en la investigación de cultivos espaciales. La NASA usará los datos que recojan para mejorar cómo se cultivan las plantas en el espacio, apoyando misiones más largas y difíciles. Este trabajo también ayuda a formar a la próxima generación de científicos y exploradores.

**Conclusión en una frase** – A través de Growing Beyond Earth, miles de estudiantes están ayudando a la NASA a cultivar alimentos para astronautas, convirtiendo las aulas en lugares donde comienza la exploración espacial.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a diverse group of glowing seedlings growing inside transparent, futuristic plant chambers that resemble miniature spacecraft, set against a softly illuminated backdrop blending a lush botanical garden with a starry night sky and distant planets, symbolizing the connection between student classrooms on Earth and NASA’s space crop research.

articles.title: What is BioSentinel?
articles.summary: Editor’s Note: This article was updated Nov. 21, 2025 shortly after BioSentinel’s mission marked three years of operation in deep space. Astronauts live in a pretty extreme environment aboard the International Space Station. Orbiting about 250 miles above the Earth in the weightlessness of microgravity, they rely on commercial cargo missions about every two months to deliver new […]
articles.content:
llustration of BioSentinel’s spacecraft flying past the Moon. NASA/Daniel Rutter

Editor’s Note: This article was updated Nov. 21, 2025 shortly after BioSentinel’s mission marked three years of operation in deep space.

Astronauts live in a pretty extreme environment aboard the International Space Station. Orbiting about 250 miles above the Earth in the weightlessness of microgravity, they rely on commercial cargo missions about every two months to deliver new supplies and experiments. And yet, this place is relatively protected in terms of space radiation. The Earth’s magnetic field shields space station crew from much of the radiation that can damage the DNA in our cells and lead to serious health problems. When future astronauts set off on long journeys deeper into space, they will be venturing into more perilous radiation environments and will need substantial protection. With the help of a biology experiment within a small satellite called BioSentinel, scientists at NASA’s Ames Research Center, in California’s Silicon Valley, are taking an early step toward finding solutions.

To learn the basics of what happens to life in space, researchers often use “model organisms” that we understand relatively well. This helps show the differences between what happens in space and on Earth more clearly. For BioSentinel, NASA is using yeast – the very same yeast that makes bread rise and beer brew. In both our cells and yeast cells, the type of high-energy radiation encountered in deep space can cause breaks in the two entwined strands of DNA that carry genetic information. Often, DNA damage can be repaired by cells in a process that is very similar between yeast and humans.

Conceptual graphic of a radiation particle causing a double-stranded DNA break.

BioSentinel set out to be the first long-duration biology experiment to take place beyond where the space station orbits near Earth. BioSentinel’s spacecraft is one of 10 CubeSats that launched aboard Artemis I, the first flight of the Artemis program’s Space Launch System, NASA’s powerful new rocket. The cereal box-sized satellite traveled to deep space on the rocket then flew past the Moon in a direction to orbit the Sun. Once the satellite was in position beyond our planet’s protective magnetic field, the BioSentinel team triggered a series of experiments remotely, activating two strains of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to grow in the presence of space radiation. Samples of yeast were activated at different time points throughout the six- to twelve-month mission.

One strain is the yeast commonly found in nature, while the other was selected because it has trouble repairing its DNA. By comparing how the two strains respond to the deep space radiation environment, researchers will learn more about the health risks posed to humans during long-term exploration and be able to develop informed strategies for reducing potential damage.

During the initial phase of the mission, which began in December 2022 and completed in April 2023, the BioSentinel team successfully operated BioSentinel’s BioSensor hardware – a miniature biotechnology laboratory designed to measure how living yeast cells respond to long-term exposure to space radiation – in deep space. The team completed four experiments lasting two-weeks each but did not observe any yeast cell growth. They determined that deep space radiation was not the cause of the inactive yeast cells, but that their lack of growth was likely due to the yeast expiring after extended storage time of the spacecraft ahead of launch.

Although the yeast did not activate as intended to gather observations on the impact of radiation on living yeast cells, BioSentinel’s onboard radiation detector – that measures the type and dose of radiation hitting the spacecraft – continues to collect data in deep space.

Jesse Fusco, left, and James Milsk, right, at the BioSentinel command console at the Multi-Mission Operations Center at NASA’s Ames Research Center in Silicon Valley. The team is receiving spacecraft telemetry at the three-year timepoint since the mission launched on Artemis I. BioSentinel continues to fly in its heliocentric orbit, now more than 48 million miles from Earth. NASA/Don Richey

NASA has extended BioSentinel’s mission to continue collecting valuable deep space radiation data in the unique, high-radiation environment beyond low Earth orbit.

The Sun has an 11-year cycle, in which solar activity rises and falls in the form of powerful solar flares and giant eruptions called coronal mass ejections. As the solar cycle progresses from maximum to a declining phase, scientists expect strong solar activity to continue through 2026, with some of the strongest storms seen during this declining phase. These events send powerful bursts of energy, magnetic fields, and plasma into space which causes the aurora and can interfere with satellite signals. Solar radiation events from particles accelerated to high speeds can also pose a threat to astronauts in space.

Built on a history of small-satellite biology

The BioSentinel project builds on Ames’ history of carrying out biology studies in space using CubeSats – small satellites built from individual units each about four inches cubed. BioSentinel is a six-unit spacecraft weighing about 30 pounds. It houses the yeast cells in tiny compartments inside microfluidic cards – custom hardware that allows for the controlled flow of extremely small volumes of liquids that will activate and sustain the yeast. Data about radiation levels and the yeast’s growth and metabolism will be collected and stored aboard the spacecraft and then transmitted to the science team back on Earth.

A reserve set of microfluidic cards containing yeast samples will be activated if the satellite encounters a solar particle event, a radiation storm coming from the Sun that is a particularly severe health risk for future deep space explorers.

BioSentinel’s microfluidics card, designed at NASA’s Ames Research Center in Silicon Valley, California, will be used to study the impact of interplanetary space radiation on yeast. Once in orbit, the growth and metabolic activity of the yeast will be measured using a three-color LED detection system and a dye that provides a readout of yeast cell activity. Here, pink wells contain actively growing yeast cells that have turned the dye from blue to pink color. NASA/Dominic Hart

Multiple BioSentinels will compare various gravity and radiation environments

In addition to the pioneering BioSentinel mission that will traverse the deep space environment, identical experiments take place under different radiation and gravity conditions. One ran on the space station, in microgravity that is similar to deep space, but with comparatively less radiation. Other experiments took place on the ground, for comparison with Earth’s gravity and radiation levels. These additional versions show scientists how to compare Earth and space station-based science experiments – which can be conducted much more readily – to the fierce radiation that future astronauts will encounter in space.

Taken together, the BioSentinel data will be critical for interpreting the effects of space radiation exposure, reducing the risks associated with long-term human exploration, and confirming existing models of the effects of space radiation on living organisms.

Milestones

December 2021: The BioSentinel ISS Control experiment launched to the International Space Station aboard SpaceX’s 24th commercial resupply services mission.

January 2022: The BioSentinel ISS Control experiment began science operations aboard the International Space Station.

February 2022: The BioSentinel ISS Control experiment began ground control science operations at NASA Ames.

June 2022: The BioSentinel ISS Control experiment completed science operations. The hardware was returned to Earth in August aboard SpaceX’s CRS-25 Dragon.

October 2022: The BioSentinel ISS Control experiment completed ground control science operations at NASA Ames.

Nov. 16, 2022: BioSentinel launched to deep space aboard Artemis I.

Dec. 5, 2022: BioSentinel began science operations in deep space.

Dec. 19, 2022: BioSentinel began ground control science operations at NASA Ames.

Nov. 16, 2024: BioSentinel marks two years of continuous radiation observations in deep space, now more than 30 million miles from Earth.

Nov. 16, 2025: BioSentinel marks three years of continuous radiation observations in deep space, now more than 48 million miles from Earth.

Partners:

NASA Ames leads the science, hardware design and development of the BioSentinel mission.

Partner organizations include NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston and NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California.

BioSentinel is funded by the Mars Campaign Development (MCO) Division within the Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate at NASA headquarters in Washington.

BioSentinel’s extended mission is supported by the Heliophysics Division of NASA’s Science Mission Directorate at NASA headquarters in Washington, the MCO, and the NASA Electronic Parts and Packaging Program within NASA’s Space Technology Mission Directorate at NASA Headquarters in Washington.

Learn more:

For researchers:

NASA Space Station Research Explorer: BioSentinel ISS Control Experiment

NASA technical webpage: BioSentinel

For news media:
articles.reasoning: BioSentinel represents a significant scientific mission providing valuable data on the effects of deep space radiation on living organisms, crucial for future human space exploration. It has broad significance for space science and astronaut health, with detailed context on the experiment, its goals, and ongoing data collection.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s BioSentinel mission studies deep space radiation effects with yeast experiment
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is preparing for future space missions that will take astronauts beyond the protection of Earth’s magnetic field. In deep space, radiation levels are much higher and can damage DNA, which could harm astronauts’ health. To understand these risks, NASA launched BioSentinel, a small satellite carrying yeast cells to study how space radiation affects living organisms.

**What happened** – BioSentinel launched in November 2022 aboard the Artemis I rocket and traveled beyond the Moon into deep space. It carries two types of yeast: one normal and one with a DNA repair problem. The satellite activates these yeast samples at different times to see how radiation affects their growth and DNA repair. Although the yeast did not grow in the first experiments due to storage issues, BioSentinel’s radiation detector continues to collect important data on space radiation.

**Impact** – This mission is the first long-term biology experiment outside Earth’s magnetic shield, providing unique information about space radiation in a real deep space environment. The data help scientists understand the risks astronauts will face on long missions to the Moon, Mars, or beyond. By comparing yeast responses in deep space with experiments on the International Space Station and Earth, researchers can better predict and protect human health in space.

**What’s next step** – NASA has extended BioSentinel’s mission to continue gathering radiation data. The satellite will activate reserve yeast samples during solar storms, which are times of especially strong radiation. This ongoing work will improve safety guidelines and technology for future deep space explorers.

**One-sentence takeaway** – BioSentinel is providing vital new information about how deep space radiation affects living cells, helping prepare humans for safer long-term space travel.
articles.personality_title_fr: La mission BioSentinel de la NASA étudie les effets des radiations spatiales sur la levure
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA prépare des missions spatiales futures qui emmèneront les astronautes au-delà du bouclier magnétique protecteur de la Terre. Dans l’espace profond, les niveaux de radiation sont beaucoup plus élevés et peuvent endommager l’ADN, ce qui pourrait nuire à la santé des astronautes. Pour comprendre ces risques, la NASA a lancé BioSentinel, un petit satellite transportant des cellules de levure pour étudier comment les radiations spatiales affectent les organismes vivants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – BioSentinel a été lancé en novembre 2022 à bord de la fusée Artemis I et a voyagé au-delà de la Lune dans l’espace profond. Il transporte deux types de levure : une normale et une avec un problème de réparation de l’ADN. Le satellite active ces échantillons de levure à différents moments pour observer comment les radiations affectent leur croissance et la réparation de l’ADN. Bien que la levure n’ait pas poussé lors des premiers essais à cause de problèmes de stockage, le détecteur de radiation de BioSentinel continue de collecter des données importantes sur les radiations spatiales.

**Impact** – Cette mission est la première expérience biologique à long terme en dehors du bouclier magnétique terrestre, fournissant des informations uniques sur les radiations spatiales dans un vrai environnement d’espace profond. Ces données aident les scientifiques à comprendre les risques auxquels les astronautes seront exposés lors de longues missions vers la Lune, Mars ou au-delà. En comparant les réponses de la levure dans l’espace profond avec des expériences à bord de la Station spatiale internationale et sur Terre, les chercheurs peuvent mieux prévoir et protéger la santé humaine dans l’espace.

**Prochaine étape** – La NASA a prolongé la mission BioSentinel pour continuer à recueillir des données sur les radiations. Le satellite activera des échantillons de levure de réserve lors des tempêtes solaires, moments de radiation particulièrement intense. Ce travail continu améliorera les consignes de sécurité et les technologies pour les futurs explorateurs de l’espace profond.

**En une phrase** – BioSentinel fournit des informations essentielles sur l’effet des radiations de l’espace profond sur les cellules vivantes, aidant à préparer des voyages spatiaux long terme plus sûrs.
articles.personality_title_es: La misión BioSentinel de la NASA estudia los efectos de la radiación espacial en levaduras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA se está preparando para futuras misiones espaciales que llevarán a los astronautas más allá del campo magnético protector de la Tierra. En el espacio profundo, los niveles de radiación son mucho más altos y pueden dañar el ADN, lo que podría afectar la salud de los astronautas. Para comprender estos riesgos, la NASA lanzó BioSentinel, un pequeño satélite que lleva células de levadura para estudiar cómo la radiación espacial afecta a los organismos vivos.

**Qué pasó** – BioSentinel fue lanzado en noviembre de 2022 a bordo del cohete Artemis I y viajó más allá de la Luna hacia el espacio profundo. Lleva dos tipos de levadura: una normal y otra con problemas para reparar su ADN. El satélite activa estas muestras de levadura en diferentes momentos para ver cómo la radiación afecta su crecimiento y reparación del ADN. Aunque la levadura no creció en los primeros experimentos debido a problemas de almacenamiento, el detector de radiación de BioSentinel sigue recopilando datos importantes sobre la radiación en el espacio.

**Impacto** – Esta misión es el primer experimento biológico a largo plazo fuera del campo magnético protector de la Tierra, proporcionando información única sobre la radiación en un entorno real de espacio profundo. Los datos ayudan a los científicos a entender los riesgos para los astronautas en misiones largas a la Luna, Marte o más allá. Al comparar las respuestas de la levadura en el espacio profundo con experimentos en la Estación Espacial Internacional y en la Tierra, los investigadores pueden predecir y proteger mejor la salud humana en el espacio.

**Próximo paso** – La NASA ha extendido la misión BioSentinel para seguir recopilando datos sobre radiación. El satélite activará muestras de levadura de reserva durante tormentas solares, que son momentos de radiación especialmente fuerte. Este trabajo continuo mejorará las normas de seguridad y la tecnología para futuros exploradores del espacio profundo.

**Una frase clave** – BioSentinel está proporcionando información vital sobre cómo la radiación del espacio profundo afecta a las células vivas, ayudando a preparar viajes espaciales largos más seguros.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a small, cube-shaped satellite gently orbiting beyond a softly glowing crescent Moon, with delicate, stylized strands of DNA floating nearby, subtly intertwined with glowing yeast cells inside transparent compartments, all rendered in natural, muted tones to evoke deep space exploration and biological discovery.

articles.title: Astronomers may have glimpsed evidence of the biggest stars ever seen
articles.summary: The distant universe might be littered with supermassive stars between 1000 and 10,000 times the mass of the sun, which could solve a cosmic mystery about the origins of extremely large black holes
articles.content:
The distant universe might be littered with supermassive stars between 1000 and 10,000 times the mass of the sun, which could solve a cosmic mystery about the origins of extremely large black holes

Artist’s impression of a field of Population III stars 100 million years after the big bang NOIRLab/NSF/AURA/J. da Silva/Spaceengine/M. Zamani

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is allowing astronomers to examine distant galaxies in the far reaches of the early universe for the first time. Some of these have chemical signatures that seem to point to exotic supermassive stars with masses up to 10,000 times that of the sun.

These behemoths are bizarre because for stars in the nearby universe, there seems to be an innate size limit. “All of our evolution models of the galaxies… rely on the fact that stars cannot be more massive than 120 solar masses or so,” says Devesh Nandal at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Massachusetts. “There, of course, have been theoretical ideas that explore stars… more massive than that, but never has there ever been a real observation that one can point to.”

That is, until now. Nandal and his colleagues examined JWST observations of a distant galaxy called GS 3073 and found unusually high amounts of nitrogen in its chemical signatures. This isn’t entirely anomalous: high nitrogen levels have been seen in several other galaxies at similarly high distances.

However, for most of the other galaxies, the nitrogen levels aren’t quite high enough to cause any confusion – certain types of relatively normal stars and other cosmic events can explain them. That’s not the case for GS 3073, Nandal says. It simply has way too much nitrogen.

There is a particular type of hypothesised primordial star, called a Population III star, that models indicate could grow extremely large. When these stars do so, the simulations also show that they should form much more nitrogen than regular stars. Nandal and his colleagues calculated that just a few Population III stars with masses between 1000 and 10,000 times that of the sun could account for the excess nitrogen in GS 3073. “Our work shows the strongest evidence to date of Population III supermassive stars in the early universe,” he says.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

However, some other researchers question whether supermassive Population III stars are the only fit for the data – or if they fit quite right at all. “Population III must be associated with a near-pristine environment” without many elements heavier than helium, says Roberto Maiolino at the University of Cambridge. “On the contrary, GS 3073 is chemically a fairly mature galaxy. So it does not seem to match the kind of environment where you expect to find Population III.”

This may simply be a strange galaxy, though, says John Regan at Maynooth University in Ireland. “When we have observations of the early universe, all we see are really weird, really exotic galaxies. So it’s hard to turn around and say yeah, but I don’t expect supermassive stars to form because that’d be too weird. Well, you just said that these are really weird,” he says.

If these colossal stars really do exist, it could help researchers understand the origins of supermassive black holes, which exist far earlier in the universe than they ought to. If they formed from supermassive stars rather than normal ones, that would give them a head start, which could explain how they grew to the enormous sizes that we see in a relatively short amount of time.

Confirming that GS 3073 and other nitrogen-rich galaxies in the early universe really do contain supermassive stars will be difficult, likely requiring the discovery of more chemical signatures of these strange giants. “Strengthening the argument for their existence is flat-out hard – it’s very hard for us to have a smoking gun signature,” says Regan. “But this signature is very strong.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery with broad implications for understanding the early universe and the origins of supermassive black holes. It presents strong evidence from the James Webb Space Telescope for the existence of supermassive Population III stars, a breakthrough in astronomy that could solve a longstanding cosmic mystery. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a major advancement in space science with potential wide-reaching impact.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers find strong signs of supermassive stars in the early universe
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long believed that stars have a size limit, usually not more than about 120 times the mass of our sun. But some cosmic mysteries, like how supermassive black holes formed so quickly after the Big Bang, suggest there might be much larger stars in the early universe.

**What happened** – Using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), astronomers studied a distant galaxy called GS 3073 and found unusually high amounts of nitrogen in its light. This chemical clue points to the possible existence of very large stars known as Population III stars, which may be between 1,000 and 10,000 times heavier than the sun. These stars have never been observed before but were predicted by models to exist long ago.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it offers the strongest evidence yet that supermassive stars once existed. If true, these giant stars could explain how supermassive black holes formed so quickly in the early universe, solving a long-standing puzzle. It changes our understanding of how stars and galaxies began.

**What's next step** – Scientists need to find more examples of galaxies like GS 3073 and look for similar chemical signs to confirm the presence of supermassive Population III stars. This will help prove if these stars really existed and how common they were in the early universe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New observations from the James Webb Space Telescope suggest that enormous stars, much bigger than any seen before, may have existed shortly after the Big Bang and helped create the universe’s first supermassive black holes.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes détectent des signes forts d’étoiles supermassives dans l’univers primitif
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques pensaient depuis longtemps que les étoiles ne pouvaient pas dépasser environ 120 fois la masse du Soleil. Mais certains mystères cosmiques, comme la formation rapide des trous noirs supermassifs après le Big Bang, suggèrent qu’il pourrait y avoir eu des étoiles beaucoup plus grandes dans l’univers ancien.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce au télescope spatial James Webb (JWST), des astronomes ont étudié une galaxie lointaine appelée GS 3073 et ont découvert des quantités très élevées d’azote dans sa lumière. Ce signe chimique indique la possible existence d’étoiles très grandes, appelées étoiles de Population III, pesant entre 1 000 et 10 000 fois la masse du Soleil. Ces étoiles n’avaient jamais été observées auparavant, mais leur existence avait été prédite.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle offre la preuve la plus forte à ce jour que des étoiles supermassives ont existé. Si c’est vrai, ces géantes pourraient expliquer comment les trous noirs supermassifs se sont formés si rapidement dans l’univers primitif, résolvant ainsi un mystère ancien. Cela change notre compréhension de la naissance des étoiles et des galaxies.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les scientifiques doivent trouver d’autres galaxies comme GS 3073 et chercher des signes chimiques similaires pour confirmer la présence des étoiles supermassives de Population III. Cela aidera à prouver si ces étoiles ont vraiment existé et à quelle fréquence dans l’univers ancien.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – De nouvelles observations du télescope James Webb suggèrent que des étoiles énormes, bien plus grandes que toutes celles déjà vues, ont peut-être existé peu après le Big Bang et ont aidé à créer les premiers trous noirs supermassifs de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos encuentran fuertes indicios de estrellas supermasivas en el universo temprano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han creído durante mucho tiempo que las estrellas no pueden ser más grandes que unas 120 veces la masa de nuestro sol. Pero algunos misterios cósmicos, como cómo se formaron los agujeros negros supermasivos tan rápido después del Big Bang, sugieren que pudo haber estrellas mucho más grandes en el universo temprano.

**Qué pasó** – Usando el telescopio espacial James Webb (JWST), los astrónomos estudiaron una galaxia distante llamada GS 3073 y encontraron cantidades inusualmente altas de nitrógeno en su luz. Esta pista química apunta a la posible existencia de estrellas muy grandes llamadas estrellas de Población III, que podrían tener entre 1,000 y 10,000 veces la masa del sol. Estas estrellas nunca se habían observado antes, pero fueron predichas por modelos.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque ofrece la evidencia más fuerte hasta ahora de que existieron estrellas supermasivas. Si es cierto, estas estrellas gigantes podrían explicar cómo se formaron los agujeros negros supermasivos tan rápido en el universo temprano, resolviendo un misterio de larga data. Cambia nuestra comprensión de cómo comenzaron las estrellas y galaxias.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos necesitan encontrar más galaxias como GS 3073 y buscar señales químicas similares para confirmar la presencia de estrellas supermasivas de Población III. Esto ayudará a probar si estas estrellas realmente existieron y cuán comunes eran en el universo temprano.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevas observaciones del telescopio James Webb sugieren que enormes estrellas, mucho más grandes que cualquier otra vista antes, pudieron haber existido poco después del Big Bang y ayudaron a crear los primeros agujeros negros supermasivos del universo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of an ancient cosmic landscape featuring colossal, glowing star-like orbs clustered together, each radiating intense golden and warm amber light with subtle nitrogen-inspired blue highlights, set against a backdrop of a distant early galaxy swirling with soft purples and deep blues, symbolizing the birth of supermassive primordial stars in the young universe.
